title: What did democracy really mean in Athens? - Melissa Schwartzberg

options.label: C
options.text: The principle of aristocracy, or rule by the best.

options.label: D
options.text: The principle of meritocracy, or rule by the most capable.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To serve as a court of law.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: The principle of democracy, or rule by the many.

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To deliberate and make decisions on public policy.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between a deliberative poll and a citizens' assembly?

options.label: A
options.text: A deliberative poll is a more formal and structured process, while a citizens' assembly is a more informal and flexible process.

options.label: B
options.text: A deliberative poll is a more representative and diverse process, while a citizens' assembly is a more homogeneous and uniform process.

options.label: C
options.text: A deliberative poll is a more permanent and ongoing process, while a citizens' assembly is a more temporary and one-time process.

options.label: D
options.text: A deliberative poll is a more expensive and resource-intensive process, while a citizens' assembly is a more cost-effective and efficient process.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of using sortition in governance?

options.label: A
options.text: It ensures that power is concentrated in the hands of a few individuals.

options.label: B
options.text: It ensures that power is distributed among the many, rather than the few.

options.label: C
options.text: It ensures that decisions are made quickly and efficiently.

options.label: D
options.text: It ensures that decisions are made slowly and inefficiently.

multiple-choice.question: What is the limitation of using sortition in governance?

options.label: A
options.text: It can be difficult to ensure that the selected individuals are representative of the population.

options.label: B
options.text: It can be difficult to ensure that the selected individuals have the necessary skills and expertise.

options.label: C
options.text: It can be difficult to ensure that the selected individuals are accountable to the public.

options.label: D
options.text: It can be difficult to ensure that the selected individuals are motivated to make decisions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the future of sortition in governance?

options.label: A
options.text: It will become more widely used and accepted as a form of governance.

options.label: B
options.text: It will become less widely used and accepted as a form of governance.

options.label: C
options.text: It will remain a niche and experimental form of governance.

options.label: D
options.text: It will become a dominant form of governance.

title: Plato’s Allegory of the Cave - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of Plato's Allegory of the Cave?

options.label: A
options.text: The allegory is a story about a group of prisoners who are freed from a cave and learn to appreciate the beauty of the outside world.

options.label: B
options.text: The allegory is an analogy for the philosopher's struggle to educate the public and highlights the difficulty of breaking free from ignorance and societal norms.

options.label: C
options.text: The allegory is a story about a group of prisoners who are chained in a cave and can only see shadows of objects cast by a fire behind them.

options.label: D
options.text: The allegory is a story about a group of prisoners who are freed from a cave and return to their normal lives.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The theory of forms holds that ideal forms are the ultimate reality and that physical objects are just imperfect reflections.

options.label: D
options.text: The theory of forms holds that ideal forms are just abstract concepts and that physical objects are the ultimate reality.

options.label: A
options.text: To provide a critique of Athenian democracy.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To provide a description of the ideal society.

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The shadows represent the flawed reflections of ideal forms.

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: Are ideal forms the ultimate reality?

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: Ideal forms are the ultimate reality.

options.label: D
options.text: Ideal forms are just abstract concepts.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They represent the difficulty of breaking free from ignorance and societal norms.

options.text: How to represent the physical world in the ideal forms.

options.label: D
options.text: How to represent the ideal forms in the physical world.

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: The ideal forms are the ultimate reality.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

title: Why do buildings fall in earthquakes? - Vicki V. May

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of building collapse during earthquakes?

options.label: A
options.text: The ground shaking violently or splitting apart

options.label: B
options.text: The displacement of the foundation and lower levels of a building

options.label: C
options.text: The building's height and material type

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between a building's mass and its natural frequency?

options.label: A
options.text: Mass and natural frequency are directly proportional

options.label: B
options.text: Mass and natural frequency are inversely proportional

options.label: C
options.text: Mass and natural frequency have no relationship

options.label: D
options.text: Mass and natural frequency are unrelated

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect known as resonance?

options.label: A
options.text: When a building's vibrations match the frequency of the earthquake's seismic waves

options.label: B
options.text: When a building's vibrations are opposite to the frequency of the earthquake's seismic waves

options.label: C
options.text: When a building's vibrations are not affected by the earthquake's seismic waves

options.label: D
options.text: When a building's vibrations are not present

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of base isolation in building design?

options.label: C
options.text: To isolate the foundation's displacement from the rest of the building

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of tuned mass damper systems?

options.label: C
options.text: To cancel out resonance by oscillating out of phase with the natural frequency

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between a building's height and its stiffness?

options.label: A
options.text: Shorter buildings are stiffer and shift less

options.label: B
options.text: Taller buildings are stiffer and shift less

options.label: C
options.text: There is no relationship between a building's height and stiffness

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of engineers working with geologists and seismologists?

options.label: A
options.text: To predict the frequency of earthquake motions at building sites

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of low frequencies of motion on buildings?

options.label: A
options.text: Low frequencies of motion cause more damage to taller and more flexible buildings

options.label: B
options.text: Low frequencies of motion cause less damage to taller and more flexible buildings

options.label: C
options.text: Low frequencies of motion have no effect on buildings

options.label: D
options.text: Low frequencies of motion cause more damage to shorter and stiffer buildings

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of high frequencies of motion on buildings?

options.label: A
options.text: High frequencies of motion cause more damage to taller and more flexible buildings

options.label: B
options.text: High frequencies of motion cause less damage to taller and more flexible buildings

options.label: C
options.text: High frequencies of motion have no effect on buildings

options.label: D
options.text: High frequencies of motion cause more damage to shorter and stiffer buildings

title: Why the Arctic is climate change's canary in the coal mine - William Chapman

multiple-choice.question: What is the Arctic often referred to as in terms of predicting the impact of climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced temperature differences between the two regions

options.label: B
options.text: Increased temperature differences between the two regions

options.label: C
options.text: No change in temperature differences between the two regions

options.label: D
options.text: A slower warming rate at the North Pole compared to the equator

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The decreased impact of positive feedbacks

options.label: C
options.text: The increased impact of negative feedbacks

options.label: D
options.text: The decreased impact of negative feedbacks

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To study the effects of climate change on the Arctic region

options.label: D
options.text: To study the effects of climate change on the rest of the planet

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: A positive feedback loop reduces the initial change, while a negative feedback loop amplifies the initial change

options.label: C
options.text: A positive feedback loop has no effect on the initial change, while a negative feedback loop has a negative effect on the initial change

options.label: D
options.text: A positive feedback loop has a negative effect on the initial change, while a negative feedback loop has no effect on the initial change

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason for the increased impact of positive feedbacks, including a faster warming rate at the North Pole compared to the equator?

options.label: A
options.text: The increased temperature differences between the two regions

options.label: B
options.text: The reduced temperature differences between the two regions

options.label: C
options.text: The increased impact of negative feedbacks

options.label: D
